subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: More stuff on Clearscript
msgSnippet: Thx Michael for the clarification but doesn t it sort of violates the phonetic spelling principles where 1 sign supposed to stand for 1 sound? B. J. ... in
messageBody:
Thx Michael for the clarification but doesn't it sort of "violates" the phonetic spelling
principles where 1 sign supposed to stand for 1 sound?
 
B. J.  

"Michael A. Rouse" <mrouse@...> wrote:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sue Nudies down the Lane
<suebee2000_miss@y...> wrote:
> Michael,
> 
> Correct me if I am wrong but you do not have a letter for "ch" like
in "chair" but do have
> a "ch" as in the Scottish "loch". How come? Or do you intended its
use for both sounds?
> 
> B. J.

You're right. Since /ch/ and /j/ are affricates, the "ch" in chair can
be represented as t+sh, and the j in judge can be the be d+zh symbols.
If one really wanted he or she could drop the /ch/ in loch and use
that symbol and its mirror image as the unvoiced/voice pair.

Mike Rouse
mrouse@...

Thx Michael for the clarification but doesn't it sort of "violates" the phonetic spelling
principles where 1 sign supposed to stand for 1 sound?
 
B. J.  

"Michael A. Rouse" <mrouse@...> wrote:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sue Nudies down the Lane
<suebee2000_miss@y...> wrote:
> Michael,
>  
> Correct me if I am wrong but you do not have a letter for "ch" like
in "chair" but do have
> a "ch" as in the Scottish "loch". How come? Or do you intended its
use for both sounds?
>  
> B. J.

You're right. Since /ch/ and /j/ are affricates, the "ch" in chair can
be represented as t+sh, and the j in judge can be the be d+zh symbols.
If one really wanted he or she could drop the /ch/ in loch and use
that symbol and its mirror image as the unvoiced/voice pair.

Mike Rouse
mrouse@...
